Romulus, the maybe mythical, maybe real
founder and first king of Rome, had a
problem. With an increasing number of
festivals, feasts, military ceremonies,
and religious celebrations to keep track
of, Romans needed a calendar to organize
all of them. Ancient astronomers already
had accurate calculations for the time
between two solar equinoxes or
solstesses. But nature had given people
a nice easy pie chart in the sky to
track the passage of time. So early
Rome, like many other cultures, worked
off a lunar calendar. The calendar of
the Romulan Republic had 10 months of
either 30 or 31 days, beginning in March
and ending in December. And we can still
see traces of that calendar today.
Problem was that year was a few days
short of four seasons. Romans were too

just start the next year on the new moon
before the spring equinox. It's actually

rounded his year up to 355. Numa split
the remaining days into two months and
tacked them on to the end of the year.
